title: Transparency
section: Memorandum of Association (MOA): Core Object Areas
text:
Memorandum of Association (MOA): Core Object Areas

1) Research, Evidence, and Community Implementation

Public health and epidemiology research
Implementation and operational research
Evidence synthesis and policy translation
Field-based public health innovation



2) Research Support and Capacity Building

Protocol and study design support
Biostatistics and data services
Manuscript and publication support
Training, workshops, fellowships, internships



3) Public Health Programs and CSR Implementation

Program design and execution
Health promotion and prevention activities
Collaborations with government, academia, NGOs, and private partners



Incidental/Ancillary Objects

National and international collaboration
Receiving lawful grants, donations, and CSR funds
Publishing reports and educational materials
Conducting conferences and technical events

title: Transparency
text:
Articles of Association (AOA): Governance Framework

Membership

Initial members are MOA subscribers
New members require unanimous existing-member approval plus Board approval
No open or automatic membership



Board and Governance

Minimum two directors; up to fifteen as per law
Board manages operations under MOA/AOA
Director removal by special resolution



Founder/President Framework

Founder status is recognized as conceptual origin
President role is governance-advisory, not automatic Board voting authority
No automatic financial privilege from founder/president role



Divisional Structure (Operational)
Planned internal divisions include:

Research and Evidence
Public Health Implementation
Collaboration and Partnerships
Accounts and Legal Compliance
Software and Systems
Education and Fellowship
Monitoring, Evaluation, Impact, and Ethics
Grants, Funding, and Resource Mobilization

title: Transparency
section: Application of Income and Winding Up
text:
Application of Income and Winding Up

Income and property are applied only toward company objects
No dividend/bonus/profit distribution to members
On dissolution, assets transfer to a similar Section 8 entity, not members

title: Transparency
text:
Financial and Reporting Status

Annual reports: To be published after first reporting cycle
Audited statements: To be published after first statutory audit
Program utilization summaries: To be published after operations begin

title: Transparency

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
This site documents a reproducible, AI-assisted workflow for public health data analysis with R.



AI-assisted code generation
Data cleaning and validation, variable labeling and reference categories
Exporting data for R, SPSS, and Stata


⚠️ This is a template document.







R is the core statistical computing environment used for data cleaning and analysis.
Visit the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN): https://cran.r-project.org
Download and install R for your operating system:

Windows
macOS
Linux

Accept default installation settings.
After installation, verify R by opening it and running:

version




RStudio is an integrated development environment (IDE) that makes working with R scripts, projects, and Quarto documents easier.
Download RStudio Desktop (Free version): https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Install RStudio after R is installed.
Open RStudio and confirm it detects your R installation.



Run the following once inside RStudio:

install.packages(c(
  "dplyr",
  "janitor",
  "skimr",
  "jsonlite",
  "ellmer",
  "haven",
  "labelled",
  "rio",
  "ollamar"
))




For environments where cloud-based AI tools are restricted (for example hospitals and government institutions), a local large language model (LLM) can be used. This workflow supports Ollama, which runs entirely offline.



Download Ollama from: https://ollama.com
Install Ollama for your operating system (Windows/macOS/Linux).
After installation, verify Ollama is running by opening a terminal and typing:
ollama --version



Gemma is a lightweight, open-source model suitable for structured code generation tasks.
In your system terminal, run:

ollama run codegemma

(You may also use larger variants if system resources permit.)



Once Ollama is running in the background, test the connection from R:

library(ellmer)

model <- chat_ollama(
  model = "codegemma"
)

chat(model, "Respond with: Ollama is working")

If successful, the model will return a short confirmation message.





© EpiPulse
This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) licence.
You are free to share and adapt this material with appropriate attribution.



CC BY 4.0

text:

Download and install R for your operating system:

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
© EpiPulse
This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) licence.
You are free to share and adapt this material with appropriate attribution.



CC BY 4.0

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
2.1 AI Data Cleaning

2.1.1 Statement to add in methodology
“AI-assisted code generation was used for data cleaning, with all scripts reviewed and executed by the investigators.”
Always de-identify data before sending anything to AI.


2.1.2 Load and summary for AI

library(dplyr)
library(janitor)
library(skimr)
library(jsonlite)

df <- read.csv("data.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
df <- clean_names(df)

data_summary <- list(
  structure = str(df),
  missing_pct = round(colMeans(is.na(df)) * 100, 2),
  unique_character_values = df |>
    select(where(is.character)) |>
    summarise(across(everything(), ~ paste(unique(.), collapse = ", "))),
  numeric_ranges = df |>
    select(where(is.numeric)) |>
    summarise(across(everything(), ~ paste(range(., na.rm = TRUE), collapse = " - ")))
)

summary_text <- toJSON(data_summary, pretty = TRUE)

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
2.2 Setup model and API key

2.2.1 OpenAI

Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "paste_api_key")

library(ellmer)

ai_generate_cleaning_code <- function(summary_text, model) {
  prompt <- paste0(
    "You are a public health data analyst.\n\n",
    "INSTRUCTIONS:\n",
    "- Generate ONLY executable R code\n",
    "- No explanations outside code\n",
    "- Do NOT load libraries\n",
    "- Do NOT delete rows\n",
    "- Do NOT impute values\n",
    "- Do NOT change outcome definitions\n",
    "- Include comments in the R code\n\n",
    "TASKS:\n",
    "- Trim whitespace in character variables\n",
    "- Standardize categorical labels\n",
    "- Convert variables to appropriate types\n",
    "- Flag impossible numeric values\n",
    "- Create missingness flags (not imputation)\n\n",
    "DATA SUMMARY:\n",
    summary_text
  )

  response <- model$chat(prompt)
  response$content
}

prompt <- paste("Use the specified cleaning instructions and return R code only.")

response <- chat_openai(
  model = "gpt-4.1-mini",
  params = list(temperature = 0.1)
)$chat(prompt)

cleaning_code <- response$content
cat(cleaning_code)



2.2.2 Local LLM (offline, hospital-safe)
No API key required for local LLM.

library(ollamar)
library(jsonlite)

ai_generate_cleaning_code <- function(summary_text,
                                      model_name = "codegemma") {

  messages <- list(
    list(
      role = "user",
      content = paste0(
        "INSTRUCTIONS:\n",
        "- Generate ONLY executable R code\n",
        "- No explanations outside code\n",
        "- Do NOT load libraries\n",
        "- Do NOT delete rows\n",
        "- Do NOT impute values\n",
        "- Do NOT change outcome definitions\n",
        "- Include comments in the R code\n",
        "TASKS:\n",
        "- Trim whitespace in character variables\n",
        "- Standardize categorical labels\n",
        "- Convert variables to appropriate types\n",
        "- Flag impossible numeric values\n",
        "- Create missingness flags (not imputation)\n",
        "DATA SUMMARY:\n",
        summary_text
      )
    )
  )

  resp <- ollamar::chat(
    model = model_name,
    messages = messages
  )

  json <- jsonlite::fromJSON(rawToChar(resp$body))
  code <- json$message$content

  if (is.null(code) || code == "") {
    stop("Model returned empty content")
  }

  code <- gsub("^```[rR]?\\s*|```$", "", code)
  code
}

cleaning_code <- ai_generate_cleaning_code(summary_text)
cat(cleaning_code)



2.2.3 Execute after review

eval(parse(text = cleaning_code))

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
section: 2.3 AI Data Typing + Labels + Reference Categories
text:
2.3 AI Data Typing + Labels + Reference Categories
Mention this in methods (recommended):
“AI-assisted code generation was used to standardize variable types, labels, and reference categories. All code was reviewed and executed by the investigators.”

2.3.1 Load function

library(ollamar)
library(jsonlite)

ai_generate_typing_and_labels_code <- function(summary_text,
                                               model_name = "codegemma") {

  prompt <- paste0(
"You are a senior public health biostatistician and R instructor.

TASK:
Generate ONLY executable R code (no explanations outside code).

AUDIENCE:
Public health beginners (MBBS / MPH / MD Community Medicine).

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Ensure correct data types:
   - numeric -> as.numeric
   - categorical -> factor
2. Add VARIABLE LABELS (column descriptions)
3. Add VALUE LABELS for categorical variables
4. Explicitly set REFERENCE CATEGORIES using relevel()
5. Comment clearly why each reference category is chosen
6. Do NOT delete rows
7. Do NOT impute missing values
8. Do NOT load libraries
9. Assume dataframe name is `df`

REFERENCE CATEGORY RULES:
- Sex -> reference = \"Male\"
- Binary exposure -> reference = \"No\" / \"Unexposed\"
- Education -> lowest level
- Socioeconomic status -> lowest class
- Outcome variables -> DO NOT relevel

OUTPUT:
Return ONLY R code with clear comments.

DATA SUMMARY:
", summary_text
  )

  messages <- list(
    list(role = "user", content = prompt)
  )

  resp <- ollamar::chat(
    model = model_name,
    messages = messages
  )

  json <- jsonlite::fromJSON(rawToChar(resp$body))
  code <- json$message$content

  if (is.null(code) || code == "") {
    stop("Model returned empty content")
  }

  code <- gsub("^```[rR]?\\s*|```$", "", code)
  code
}



2.3.2 Generate the code

typing_label_code <- ai_generate_typing_and_labels_code(summary_text)
cat(typing_label_code)



2.3.3 Execute code after review

eval(parse(text = typing_label_code))

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
3.1 Data inspection

3.1.1 Load libraries

library(dplyr)
library(janitor)
library(skimr)



3.1.2 Load data

df <- read.csv("data.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)



3.1.3 Inspect

dim(df); names(df); str(df); summary(df)



3.1.4 Clean names

df <- clean_names(df)



3.1.5 Explore

skim(df)



3.1.6 Unique values

df |> select(where(is.character)) |> lapply(unique)



3.1.7 Missingness

colMeans(is.na(df)) * 100



3.1.8 Validate

table(df$sex)
range(df$age, na.rm = TRUE)

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
3.2 Data typing + labels + reference categories (sample)

# Ensure age is numeric
df <- df |>
  mutate(age = as.numeric(age))

# Convert sex to factor and set reference category
# Reference = Male (standard epidemiologic practice)
df <- df |>
  mutate(
    sex = factor(sex, levels = c("Male", "Female")),
    sex = relevel(sex, ref = "Male")
  )

# Convert smoking status to factor
# Reference = No (unexposed group)
df <- df |>
  mutate(
    smoking = factor(smoking, levels = c("No", "Yes")),
    smoking = relevel(smoking, ref = "No")
  )

# Education level (reference = lowest education)
df <- df |>
  mutate(
    education = factor(
      education,
      levels = c("No formal education", "Primary", "Secondary", "Higher")
    ),
    education = relevel(education, ref = "No formal education")
  )

# Add variable labels (for tables and reports)
attr(df$age, "label") <- "Age in completed years"
attr(df$sex, "label") <- "Sex of the participant"
attr(df$smoking, "label") <- "Current smoking status"
attr(df$education, "label") <- "Highest educational attainment"

title: About EpiPulse
text: EpiPulse is a Section 8 public health organization being developed to connect research quality, implementation strength, and social accountability.

title: About EpiPulse
text: EpiPulse is a Section 8 public health organization being developed to connect research quality, implementation strength, and social accountability.

title: About EpiPulse
text:
Mission, Vision, and Institutional Objective


Mission
Generate and apply high-quality public health evidence for better community outcomes and stronger systems.


Vision
Create healthier and more equitable communities through evidence-led, ethically grounded public health action.


Institutional Objective
Develop a sustainable public health institution that combines scientific rigor, implementation capacity, and transparent governance.

title: About EpiPulse
text:
Values

Scientific integrity
Equity and inclusion
Ethics and accountability
Collaboration and interdisciplinary work
Community-centered implementation

title: About EpiPulse
text:
Internal Divisions (Operational Framework)
EpiPulse is organized into the following internal divisions:

Research and Evidence Division
Public Health Implementation Division
Collaboration and Partnerships Division
Accounts and Legal Compliance Division
Software and Systems Division
Education and Fellowship Division
Monitoring, Evaluation, Impact, and Ethics Division
Grants, Funding, and Resource Mobilization Division

title: About EpiPulse
text:
Governance Note
Member and director details are maintained in official filings and project documentation, and are not publicly listed at this stage.

title: About EpiPulse
text:
Organizational Stage

Legal and operational milestones will be published after incorporation and commencement are formally completed.
Country Focus: India

For legal framework and status, visit Transparency.

title: EpiPulse
text:
Section 8 Public Health Organization



EpiPulse is building a mission-driven public health platform that links epidemiology, implementation science, and community partnerships to create measurable social benefit.
Mission and Vision Volunteer With Us

title: EpiPulse
text:
Mission, Vision, and Objectives


Mission
Generate and translate high-quality public health evidence into practical decisions, responsible implementation, and community benefit.


Vision
Build healthier, resilient, and equitable communities by connecting science, systems, and people-centered action.


Strategic Objective
Create an institution that is scientifically rigorous, ethically grounded, operationally transparent, and collaborative by design.

title: EpiPulse
text:
Core Objectives


Objective 01
Advance epidemiology and implementation research focused on real public health priorities.


Objective 02
Strengthen prevention and health-promotion programs in community settings.


Objective 03
Support institutions with training, methods, and technical public health systems inputs.


Objective 04
Embed ethics, equity, One Health thinking, and data responsibility across all workflows.

title: EpiPulse
text:
How the Mission Gets Delivered
Our mission is executed through eight internal divisions:

Research and Evidence
Public Health Implementation
Collaboration and Partnerships
Accounts and Legal Compliance
Software and Systems
Education and Fellowship
Monitoring, Evaluation, Impact, and Ethics
Grants, Funding, and Resource Mobilization

Explore division-aligned materials in the Resource Hub.

title: EpiPulse
text:
Current Stage
EpiPulse is in its setup phase. Programs, reports, and donation channels will be activated and published in line with compliance and verification standards.

Transparency and Legal Framework
Programs Roadmap
Community and Collaboration

title: Programs
text: EpiPulse programs are designed to convert mission into measurable public health action through rigorous methods, field implementation, and system collaboration.

title: Programs
text: EpiPulse programs are designed to convert mission into measurable public health action through rigorous methods, field implementation, and system collaboration.

title: Programs
text:
Mission-to-Program Domains


Epidemiology and Surveillance
Disease intelligence, risk analysis, and evidence pathways for informed decisions.


Non-Communicable Disease Prevention
Community-focused interventions on hypertension, diabetes, nutrition, and lifestyle risks.


Maternal, Child, and Adolescent Health
Life-course and school-community interventions with implementation support.


Environmental and Occupational Health
Public health responses to environmental exposures and workplace determinants.


One Health and Emerging Infections
Integrated human-animal-environment approaches to future health threats.


Education and Capacity Building
Workforce development through training, mentorship, and practical implementation tools.

title: Programs
text:
Program Objectives

Build intervention models that are evidence-based and field-feasible
Strengthen local capacity to implement and monitor public health actions
Improve transparency and reproducibility in program documentation
Align implementation with ethics, equity, and accountability

title: Programs
text:
Division Alignment for Delivery

Research and Evidence: Protocols, methods, and evidence generation
Public Health Implementation: Field execution and community operations
Collaboration and Partnerships: Institutional and CSR coordination
Accounts and Legal Compliance: Governance and statutory compliance
Software and Systems: Data systems and digital workflows
Education and Fellowship: Training and workforce development
Monitoring, Evaluation, Impact, and Ethics: Quality assurance and responsible measurement
Grants, Funding, and Resource Mobilization: Resource planning and sustainability

For division-wise templates and materials, use the Resource Hub.

title: Programs
text:
Collaboration
For collaborations, grants, and institutional partnerships, visit Contact.

title: Resource Hub
text: This page is the central academic and technical resource index for EpiPulse. It is designed to support research quality, reproducibility, ethics, and implementation readiness across all internal divisions.

title: Resource Hub
text: This page is the central academic and technical resource index for EpiPulse. It is designed to support research quality, reproducibility, ethics, and implementation readiness across all internal divisions.

title: Resource Hub
text:
Academic Objective
EpiPulse resources are developed to:

Strengthen protocol-to-publication research workflows
Improve evidence quality in public health decision-making
Build practical skills in epidemiology, analytics, and implementation
Standardize documentation, data governance, and reproducibility
Support collaborative work across research, program, and systems teams

title: Resource Hub
text:
Core Resource Collection

AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
Practical R workflow for de-identified AI-assisted data cleaning, typing, labeling, and export.
Community
Discussion space for technical questions, peer support, and method exchange.
Transparency
Legal structure, governance framework, and pre-launch operational status.

title: Resource Hub
text:
Resource Architecture by Internal Division

1) Research and Evidence Division

Protocol templates
Study design and methods notes
Evidence synthesis and review workflows
Manuscript and reporting guides



2) Public Health Implementation Division

Program design templates
Field implementation SOPs
Community intervention documentation tools
Operational learning notes



3) Collaboration and Partnerships Division

Collaboration framework notes
Partner onboarding documents
CSR-alignment concept notes
Joint implementation documentation standards



4) Accounts and Legal Compliance Division

Compliance checklist templates
Statutory reporting tracker formats
Donation policy and governance documentation
Basic audit-preparedness templates



5) Software and Systems Division

Data pipeline setup guides
Reproducible coding conventions
Version control and release notes templates
Data interoperability and export standards



6) Education and Fellowship Division

Learning modules for students and professionals
Workshop and mentorship materials
Fellowship and internship learning pathways
Competency tracking templates



7) Monitoring, Evaluation, Impact, and Ethics Division

Indicator frameworks
M&E toolkits
Ethics and data responsibility checklists
Impact reporting templates (to be activated post-launch)



8) Grants, Funding, and Resource Mobilization Division

Concept note templates
Grant narrative and budget drafting guides
Funding opportunity tracker formats
Donor communication structure templates

title: Resource Hub
text:
Recommended Path for New Users

Start with the AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
Review legal and operational status on Transparency
Use division-specific templates relevant to your workstream
Discuss practical challenges in Community
Archive outputs with clear versioning and data dictionaries
